title: 112_s1920
content: The Act is titled the "Saving Money and Reducing Tragedies through Prevention Act of 2011" or the "SMART Prevention Act of 2011." It amends the Violence Against Women Act of 1994 to focus on prevention efforts. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary of Health and Human Services and the Secretary of Education, is authorized to award grants for preventing domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by focusing on youth, children exposed to violence, and men as leaders. Funds can be used for teen dating violence awareness and prevention programs. The program should use evidence-based strategies focused on youth, including education on domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and healthy relationships. It should involve community collaboration, training for influencers like parents and teachers, and outreach to address environmental factors contributing to violence. The program aims to prevent domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by addressing children's exposure to violence in the home through services like counseling, advocacy, and support for the non-abusing parent. It also includes training and coordination for educational purposes. To prevent domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking, programs focus on training and coordinating educational, after-school, and childcare programs to identify and refer children and families experiencing violence. Additionally, engaging men as leaders and role models in violence prevention efforts is emphasized. Eligible entities must meet specific criteria to receive grants under this section. Entities eligible for grants under this section must be victim service providers, community-based organizations, tribes, or non-profit organizations with a history of effective work in preventing domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking. They should also have expertise in the specific area for which they are applying for funds, or be a partnership with at least one entity that has expertise in serving children or youth exposed to violence. Entities eligible for grants under this section must have expertise in providing services to youth in areas such as stalking, dating violence, and sexual assault. This includes schools, community-based organizations, population-specific organizations, and faith-based organizations. Entities eligible for grants under this section include organizations with a history of effective work addressing the needs of children exposed to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking, as well as entities providing services for runaway or homeless youth affected by these issues. Healthcare entities eligible for reimbursement under title XVIII of the Social Security Act are also eligible, along with other agencies, population-specific organizations, or nonprofit entities. Entities eligible for grants under this section include organizations with a history of effective work addressing the needs of children exposed to domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, or stalking, as well as entities providing services for runaway or homeless youth affected by these issues. Applicants for grants must demonstrate capacity and establish policies for appropriate victim care referral systems. The Attorney General shall give preference to grant recipients who provide follow-up care, protect victim information confidentiality, ensure training for prevention programming, and document program coordination with community services. The Attorney General gives preference to grant applicants with outcome-based evaluation and coordination with existing domestic violence prevention efforts. Definitions and grant conditions from section 40002 apply, and 'youth' includes individuals aged 11. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations totaling $15,000,000 annually for fiscal years 2012 through 2016 is provided for specific programs and activities. A minimum allocation of 25% for each purpose outlined in subsection (a) and 10% for grants to Indian tribes or tribal organizations is mandated, with reallocation to other programs if needed. Repeals sections of the Violence Against Women Act of 1994 and the Violence Against Women and Department of Justice Reauthorization Act of 2005.
